reviewText: Fantastica Caballe.We like her a lot.Now with this documentary,we got to know her even better.She's not only a soprano,she's a whole beauty of music.We have also a cd,Eternal Caballe where therein Hijo de la luna(Son of the moon)a divine masterpiece performed by a feminine beauty lyric opera singer...Monserrat Caballe,muy bonita,Caballe,me gusta.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Este documental repasa la vida personal y la carrera de la soprano catalana MONTSERRAT CABALLE, sin duda una de las mas grandes figuras de la historia de la opera. Amplia seleccion de intervenciones de la cantante (desde sus primeras intervenciones con 'Il Pirata', 'Turandot' o 'Lucrezia Borgia' hasta las últimas rarezas que exhumó como 'La Vierge' de Massenet, 'Henry VIII' de Saint-Saens, u -ofrecido como extra en el dvd- 'Cleopatre', de Massenet, solo por citar unos pocos) se alternan con una narración en primera persona de su vida, sus comienzos, su triunfo y su madurez como artista. Complementan el documental las opiniones de reputados profesionales de varios campos sobre la soprano (del mundo de la musica hablan entre otros Domingo, Abbado, Horne, Bergonzi...) completan las casi dos horas de disfrute al lado de una de las mas grandes divas que existen. Apasionante para los que, como yo, son fans de Montserrat Caballe, pero tambien muy disfrutable para los que no conozcan en profundidad a la Caballé (¿acaso queda alguien que no la conozca?) De visión más que obligada, una vez, al menos.
summary: Un bello documental honrando a Caballe
Title: N/A

reviewText: I Love the Lady. I have all -and I truly mean all- her recordings, including many commercially unreleased ones, on CDs and DVDs. But this is the single item I have seen more times, followed very closely by her 1978 Norma in Madrid and her 1974 Norma in Orange. This is a great film for anyone interested in perhaps the great last diva of opera, in music or filmaking, for that matter. Everything has been said already by previous reviewers. I would just add that I cry in a couple of moments everytime I watch this. Her story is full of emotions and the sheer pleasure of singing and music. A deeply brilliant and movig documentary. It will be a lasting and deserved homage to a great lady, a caring mother and spouse, and above all a larger than life (no pun intended) artist and woman. She was not always right but I think she was always herself and she did what she thought she had to do. And, oh my, did she do it well!
summary: I CAN'T GET ENOUGH OF THIS
Title: N/A

reviewText: I think I speak for all Montserrat Caballe fans when I say that this documentary could have gone on for three or four hours, and I still would have been enraptured!Instead of some bland documentary narrated by a male voice-over, we are treated to the story of Caballe, as told by the Prima Donna Assoluta herself.  For those who speak Spanish, this is a double treat. Yo sentia profundamente la sinceridad, calor, y alegria de La Caballe.  Cuando te cuenta las historias de su vida espectacular, es como si estuvieras defrente de ella.  Es igual con su hermano, Carlos Caballe.As previously stated by other reviewers, there is ample footage of her triumphant Bel Canto performances.  Some of these, like Roberto Devereux, were released some time back on VHS.  As most Caballe fans know, there is little that has been released to date on DVD; this documentary teases us with what we have been missing all along, at least those of us who didn't buy the VHS releases back then.Aside from the myth-making performances, there are the touching tributes and comments from others in the opera world, though I would have personally enjoyed more commentary from Dame Joan Sutherland, another Queen of Bel Canto.  Montsy does her own tributes, to Callas and Freddie Mercury.  But there is much more than that; there is Caballe singing in the streets, visiting old haunts, and even letting us into her home to meet her family.We were recently treated to another DVD release, Montserrat Caballe Bel Canto.  In addition to taped performances of whole operas, I hope that they will also release the British documentary Montserrat Caballe, where she comments on different roles, and "performs" arias from some of her extraordinary roles.As a last comment, it was a particular joy to see snippets of her recent performances in Barcelona, of long-forgotten operas.  Even being so far past her prime, she easily outshines many of the leading ladies singing today.
summary: A Tribute to a Living Legend

reviewText: We can only hope for an update of Beyond Music, perhaps based on Pullen's biography.  I have watched Beyond Music at least 4 times, and see something new each time.  There are sources for other documentary material on video, but they are either of poor quality--content and technical aspects--or in French or German, neither of which I speak or understand with any facility.  An earlier VHS  entitled something like "The Diva, the Woman", somewhat fleshes things out.  So, this is what we have.  Wish there were more.  But I'm grateful.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This 90 minute documentary was made for Catalonian Television by Antonio Farré in 2003 and has been shown in Europe, but not in the US, if I'm not mistaken. It is a detailed, loving, and well written and filmed musical biography of the great Spanish soprano. It is filled with clips from performances all over the world, starting with black & white film from Salle Pleyel in 1965 and up to 2002. There are many interviews with such luminaries as Marilyn Horne, Claudio Abbado, Zubin Mehta, José Carreras, Plácido Domingo, Renée Fleming, Joan Dorneman, Cheryl Studer, Samuel Ramey, Mstislav Rostropovich, Giuseppe di Stefano, Joan Sutherland, and more.Caballé is interviewed extensively in a number of different settings and she tells us, touchingly, of her family's commitment to her early training and of the largesse of a Barcelona family who funded her studies (and much more) when the family's money ran out. She traces her career from her first professional job in Basle and Bremen, her début in her home theater, the Liceu in Barcelona to her triumphs in the greatest opera houses in the world. There are some thrilling musical clips. Particularly so are those of her and Marilyn Horne singing the duet from 'Semiramide' (breathtakingly beautiful) and a performance by Caballé at the Thetre Antique in Orange of 'Casta diva' in what may be the most stunning performance of it I've ever heard.There are scenes with her husband, tenor Bernabé Marti, and their two children, including one touching clip from a duet performance featuring her and her now-adult daughter, also named Montserrat and herself possessor of a lovely voice, singing together. Caballé comes across as a charming, gentle (but perfectionistic and stubborn about it), and generous artist. I was touched by the closing credit that says 'This film would not have been possible without the support of my parents and the Bernard family,' the latter being the family who supported her studies all those years ago at the Liceu school.This DVD is well worth it if you admire this artist.TT=98 minutes. PCM Stereo/Dolby Digital 5.1. Subtitles in English, French and Italian.Scott Morrison
summary: A Musical Biography of Montserrat Caballé
Title: N/A

reviewText: A fittingly sumptuous, all-encompassing look at Montserrat Caballe - her life and career, and especially her family.  The archival footage of early Caballe performances is riveting, to be sure, and a thankfully sure intelligence in editing informs throughout.  The tributes and comments of other artists reveal the awe and affection for Caballe held by her peers. Many affecting moments are spent with her family - brother Carlos, whose managerial genius assured her golden career, husband Bernabe erupting in song at Caballe's birthday party, & her son and daughter reveal their mother and themselves, with insight. Caballe's temperament shines, a complete musicianship utterly rare in a singer, and will and serenity to settle the question of the source of her magical musical gifts, and the success made of them. The enigma of her collaboration with F Mercury is spotlighted, bursts of laughter with her brother, her love of the Liceu Theatre - all contribute to a compelling journey with this artist. Caballe's sensitive and compassionate remarks about Maria Callas are beautiful, and vital to the film. They reflect the passion of Montserrat Caballe: the great love she holds for her family, and for art. Docu-bios abound, this one's something special. An exceptional film at a good price. The rewards are unmistakable.
Title: N/A
